articles.author: Akhil varute
articles.description:
In today's cloud-native world, containers have become the standard deployment unit for applications. Yet despite Docker's widespread adoption, a surprising number of organizations struggle with inefficient, insecure, and problematic Dockerfiles. These issues silently drain productivity, increase costs, and introduce security vulnerabilities throughout the development lifecycle.
The numbers tell a concerning story:
The average container image in enterprise environments is 650MB - often 2-3x larger than necessary
Developers spend an average of 15-20 minutes daily waiting for Docker builds to complete
87% of container images contain at least one high or critical vulnerability
Only 35% of organizations have automated container security scanning
These statistics represent enormous waste across â€¦
articles.title: The Hidden Costs of Poorly Optimized Dockerfiles: DevOps' Silent Productivity Killer

articles.description:
This article will delve into the basic syntax and structure of the Cangjie language. These fundamental knowledge lay a solid foundation for writing efficient and maintainable code. By understanding statement structures, expressions, comments, and data types, you can use Cangjie for programming with greater confidence.
I. Basic Syntax
Assignment Statements: Used to assign values to variables.
let x: Int64 = 10
println(x)

output:10
Conditional Statements: Used to control the execution flow of a program.
if (x > 0) {
    println("x is +")  
}
output: x is +

for (i in 1..=5) {
    println(i) 
}

output: 1 2 3 4 5
Please translate the following text into English.
1.2 Expressions
Arithmetic Operations: Such as addition, subtraction, etc.
let a: Int64 = 1
let b: Int64 = 2
let sum: Int64 = a + b
println(sum)

output:3
Logical Operations: Such as AND, OR, etc.
if (a > 0 && b < 10) {
    println("a > 0 && b < 10") 
}

output:a > 0 && b < 10
II. Variable Naming and Identifiers Overview
III. Comments
3.1 Single-Line Comments
println("Welcome to Cangjie!")
output:Welcome to Cangjie!

3.2 Multi-Line Comments

func factorial(n: Int): Int {
}

IV. Data Types
Integer Typesã€Floating-Point Typesã€String Typeã€Boolean Type
let age: Int64 = 25
let height: Float64 = 1.75
let name: String = "Cangjie" 
let isAdult: Bool = true

V. Control Structures
Use if, else if, and else for conditional judgment.
The for loop and while loop are used to repeatedly execute code blocks.
Summary
This article provides a comprehensive introduction to the basic syntax and structure of the Cangjie language, including statement structures, expressions, comments, data types, and control structures. Mastering these fundamental concepts will lay a solid foundation for subsequent programming learning and serve as the basis for creating efficient and maintainable code.

articles.author: hanapiko
articles.description:
Ever built something that needed real-time updates and found yourself wondering if HTTP alone could cut it? Iâ€™ve been there too. In this post, Iâ€™ll walk you through the key differences between HTTP and WebSocket, technologies youâ€™ll often encounter when building modern web applications.
Whatâ€™s the Core Difference?
Both HTTP and WebSocket are protocols used for communication between a client and a server. But they operate very differently and that matters a lot depending on what you're building.
HTTP: Request-Response, Stateless
HTTP is the way the web communicates. A client (like your browser) sends a request, and the server sends a response. Thatâ€™s it. Once the transaction is done, the connection usually closes.
Great for:
- Web pages

- REST APIs

- Static resources

Not so great for:
- Anything that needs real-time data updates

WebSocket: Full-Duplex, Persistent
WebSocket is designed for continuous, two-way communication. After an initial handshake over HTTP, the connection upgrades to WebSocket and stays open. Both client and server can push messages to each other anytime.
Perfect for:
- Live chat

- Online games

- Stock tickers

Collaborative editing tools

HTTP runs securely over HTTPS. Well supported, widely used, and easy to scale.

WebSocket uses WSS (WebSocket Secure) for encrypted traffic. Requires a bit more care in implementation, especially with authentication and origin checks.

Both protocols are supported by all modern browsers and most cloud/server infrastructures.
If your app:
Only needs data when a user does something (like clicking a button)

Is stateless or RESTful

âœ… Use HTTP
If your app:
Needs to send or receive data without user action

Updates in real-time

ðŸ”¥ Go with WebSocket
Whether you're building a chat app or just exploring backend development, understanding the difference between HTTP and WebSocket will help you design smarter, more efficient systems.
Let me know your thoughts or experiences in the comments
articles.title: WebSocket vs HTTP: Understanding the Real Difference

articles.author: Grenish rai
articles.description:
Google I/O 2025 marked a pivotal shift to an "AI-first" strategy, embedding AI at the core of all Google products. Central to this vision is the enhanced Gemini 2.5 model, featuring advanced reasoning ("Deep Think"), native audio output, and multimodal capabilities. AI-driven agents like Project Astra and Project Mariner signal a move from simple query-response to autonomous task execution. New pricing tiers (Google AI Pro and Ultra) monetize premium features.
Search now includes an "AI mode" with conversational answers and agentic shopping tools. Workspace apps like Gmail and Meet gain AI-enhanced smart replies and real-time translations. Creators benefit from tools like Veo 3 (video generation), Flow (filmmaking), and Imagen 4 (image generation).
Developers get AI-assisted Android Studio and Chrome DevTools. Google also introduced its new Ironwood TPU for AI workloads. For future computing, AI is integrated into XR projects like Google Beam and smart glasses.
To ensure responsible AI, Google launched SynthID for watermarking AI-generated content. Overall, I/O 2025 outlined Googleâ€™s long-term AI ecosystemâ€”from everyday apps to immersive computingâ€”redefining productivity, content creation, and user interaction.
articles.title: Entire Google I/O under 200 words

When building applications with Appwrite, developers often need a way to test and debug services repeatedly over short periods. Sometimes, this can become a hassle, as Appwrite enforces strict rate limits on client apps to prevent abuse. Developers needed a way to bypass these rate limits in their test environments and CI/CD workflows to ensure the robustness of their app functionalities.
And this is the exact problem dev keys are here to solve!
Dev keys are a type of secret used by Appwrite's client SDKs. They allow the developer to bypass any rate limits enforced by Appwrite and suppress any CORS errors caused by not using a configured hostname. A developer can configure the expiration date of a dev key to any of the three preset options (1 day, 7 days, or 30 days).
Dev keys should neverâ€¦
